author: abcoathup
content: Has anyone got a summary/notes of the Rollcall Precompile breakout?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<thegaram33> here's a quick summary:

- RIP-7212: adopted by Polygon (live on testnet), zkSync (ready, rollout ETA April), Optimism, Kakarot
- Rollup registry wip: https://github.com/ethereum/RIPs/tree/rips_registry/registry. Chains that support an RIP on mainnet can be added here. Which chains -> inclusion by default, we don't want to define what a rollup is.
- What if a rollup is not fully compliant with a RIP, e.g. changes gas schedule? Generally it would count as not implementing the RIP. Multi-dimensional fees might address this.
- How to check if an RIP is implemented correctly? We could set up something similar to execution-spec-tests and reuse some of the testing setup from L1.
- Devex issues around partial support for precompiles, devs need to ensure support on each L2 they deploy on. We could use progressive precompiles but that proposal is not compatible with the RIP address range. Suggestion by @yoavw: new precompile that would allow checking RIP support on-chain in a standard way (re @ethrnd_rollcall_bot: <abcoathup> Has anyone got a summary/notes of the Rollcall Precompile breakout?)

author: abcoathup
content: Thanks have added to Eth Magicians: https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/rollcall-breakout-3-precompiles-and-the-rip-process/18508/3

author: sm_stack
content: Does anyone get the link for the rollcall telegram?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<oneski22> when a chain adds themselves as supporting a RIP, is there a field to indicate what block number it went live at? or no need to include (re @thegaram33: here's a quick summary:

- RIP-7212: adopted by Polygon (live on testnet), zkSync (ready, rollout ETA April), Optimism, Kakarot
- Rollup registry wip: https://github.com/ethereum/RIPs/tree/rips_registry/registry. Chains that support an RIP on mainnet can be added here. Which chains -> inclusion by default, we don't want to define what a rollup is.
- What if a rollup is not fully compliant with a RIP, e.g. changes gas schedule? Generally it would count as not implementing the RIP. Multi-dimensional fees might address this.
- How to check if an RIP is implemented correctly? We could set up something similar to execution-spec-tests and reuse some of the testing setup from L1.
- Devex issues around partial support for precompiles, devs need to ensure support on each L2 they deploy on. We could use progressive precompiles but that proposal is not compatible with the RIP address range. Suggestion by @yoavw: new precompile that would allow checking RIP support on-chain in a standard way)

author: bridge-bot
content: <CarlBeek> EIP-4844 L1 mainnet fork was just scheduled on ACD. Fork date is 13/03

author: bridge-bot
content: <CarlBeek> I'm not convinced there is much use for having that information in there, I'm imagining it just being something that shows the current state and if people want more details they can dig into a chain's local docs/repo. Open to pushback tho (re @oneski22: when a chain adds themselves as supporting a RIP, is there a field to indicate what block number it went live at? or no need to include)

author: bridge-bot
content: <shemnon> Perhaps this is better served by non-normative aggregation sites like https://www.rollup.codes/ . Much like https://chainlist.org/, which could also add the compliance claims.
